body: @ijuma - i guess this has been in there for a while, but it should be updated for the 0.10.0.1 release. I've deliberately raised this PR against the branch as Trunk has API changes that are not compatible with 0.10.0.

@hachikuji is this what you had in mind on KAFKA-3766?
@ijuma

I agree with @ijuma that this makes less sense in trunk, but the impact of the bug is pretty bad, so if we can't have the patch for KAFKA-3396 in 0.10.0, we should probably include this.
@dguy, please close this PR when you can (the auto-closer only works if a PR is merged to trunk).

@hachikuji ah, I misunderstood what you meant.  I'll try to update this PR with that since I agree it's better to do this on the server side altogether.  Also agree that we need to write to __consumer_offsets for OffsetCommit so it needs to be handled there as well.  

I think KAFKA-3766 can be resolved as a duplicate.  I don't have permission to change the status though, it's all you :)
The PR should target the 0.10.0 branch if we agree that the aim is to merge this there (and not trunk).

@junrao I ran test with 8500 log segments with time index files. They are loaded in less than 3.5 seconds. And it took 1.5 second without time index files. Not sure if that is equivalent to testing files with 44K, but apparently the time does not grow linearly with the number of log segments. 

The mmap results are extracted from the segment loading test. Micro benchmark which repeatedly maps a single file does not reveal this scalability issue.
Merged to the 0.10.0 branch, @dguy can you please close the PR (the auto-closer only works when a PR is merged to trunk).

@becketqin : Thanks for the new results. It feels a bit weird that the turning point is at exactly 22K segments. Also, in the "time to resize" sheet, the results seem to suggest that resizing at 10 batches with time index is 6 times more expensive than resizing at 10 batches w/o time index. This seems to be at the pointe where the number of loaded segments is still well below 22K?

Is it possible to do an experiment with 44K segments and turn off the time index? This will tell us more about whether the overhead comes from scalability related to mmap() or something else in the time index.
@hachikuji Is this fix close to what you had in mind?

@vahidhashemian I'm not sure this quite does it. It looks like this is going to keep aggregating across multiple fetches. I was actually wondering if there was a way to reuse `FetchResponseMetricAggregator` to accumulate the metrics for each topic. For example, maybe we just need to move the map from topic to `FetchMetrics` that you have here into that class. Then we can increment it accordingly in calls to `record()`. Would that work?
anyof @ewencp @ijuma @enothereska @gwenshap @sriramsub @guozhangwang @dguy @miguno

@junrao I refined the profiling code a little, I can stably reproduce the mmap() time issue. But the resize time seems to be consistent now. I'll do an experiment on a broker with ~50K segments without time index and see what happens there.

@hachikuji Thanks for the quick feedback. I believe [this line](https://github.com/vahidhashemian/kafka/blob/a69c8fe3d1a9d99310f99db4821a6d70cf06104b/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/consumer/internals/Fetcher.java#L359) would make it aggregate within the same fetch only. But I'm going to give what you suggested a try and update the PR. Thanks again.
Hmm... that still doesn't seem quite right. That resets the counts on every call to `fetchedRecords`, but the same fetch response could be split across several calls, right?
LGTM
Thank you for contributing :)
LGTM. Looks nice :)
ah, sorry - didn't notice the merge conflict. Rebase and ping me?
@ewencp Should be an easy review

A few things:
1. Can we have a JIRA for this? Generally, we want to track changes that cause a new RC in the release notes.
2. Can someone familiar with this tool test that it still works as expected?
3. Can someone send an email to the RC thread explaining that we need a new RC along with the reasoning?

OK. I think I'm still missing something. Based on what you mentioned, it seems we would want to collect metrics at a higher level (at fetch response levels instead of `fetchedRecords`).

In your first comment I believe you were referring to [this `record()` call](https://github.com/vahidhashemian/kafka/blob/131f96868aa24f38f69ee2ab769ea3f289e5c1fc/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/consumer/internals/Fetcher.java#L722) (as a member of `FetchResponseMetricAggregator`), and not the [call to `recordTopicFetchMetrics()`](https://github.com/vahidhashemian/kafka/blob/131f96868aa24f38f69ee2ab769ea3f289e5c1fc/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/consumer/internals/Fetcher.java#L556) which I thought was the culprit. That `record()` method doesn't seem to aggregate metrics per partition. It just aggregates across all partitions in the fetch response. Do we want to change that and collect per topic, or just add per-topic metric aggregation too?

Thanks a lot in advance for clearing this up.
Since the DELETE operation is only valid for the topic resource, we will need to add additional check in AclCommand.checkArgs().

@vahidhashemian Just to clarify, a single fetch response contains fetch data from multiple partitions, some of which may be from the same topic. My interpretation of the topic-level fetch metrics is that they should be recording the per-topic number of records/bytes fetched from the entire fetch response rather than from each partition separately (does this seem correct?). That means we need to aggregate these stats by topic for each fetch response. The tricky thing is that we now parse the fetch data from each partition separately, so we need somewhere to store the stats so that they can be aggregated incrementally. That is the purpose of `FetchResponseMetricAggregator`. It contains a set of all the partitions that were contained in the fetch response and as we parse the data from each partition, we remove that partition from the set. Once all partitions have been parsed, we can record the fetch metrics. So my thought was that maybe we only needed to extend that idea. In addition to keeping the total number of bytes/records from the fetch response in `FetchResponseMetricAggregator`, we can also track the per-topic tallies. Would that make sense or not?
So after discussion of public API, this seems fine as long as we can address @ijuma's points.

It would be great to address the remaining points so that we can respin a new RC for 0.10.0.1. As far as I can tell, they are:
1. Update the PR title to have the JIRA id (i.e. KAFKA-4008)
2. Retest that the tool still works after this change
3. Update javadoc of the tool to make it clear that the class is not public API, people should not expect compatibility (i.e. the package name is likely to change and there may be other incompatible changes) and the script should be used if compatibility is desired (phrased in a better way).

@hachikuji Thanks for explaining in details how you envision these metrics should be collected at topic level. It makes sense. Other than tracking, I assume we also need to "record" these per-topic metrics; perhaps through per-topic sensors. This can be done at the same time partition metrics are recorded ([here](https://github.com/vahidhashemian/kafka/blob/131f96868aa24f38f69ee2ab769ea3f289e5c1fc/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/consumer/internals/Fetcher.java#L729)). Would you agree?
@vahidhashemian Yep, I think that will work.

Confirmed, sorry that took so long. I let this one slip through the cracks but I have since tested it and it works as expected. If the SAN took precedence over CN and clients refused to connect when the expected hostname did not match the hostname in the certificate. 

Hostname verification fails with the following exception: 

kafka-producer-network-thread | console-producer, fatal error: 46: General SSLEngine problem
java.security.cert.CertificateException: No name matching localhost found
%% Invalidated:  [Session-53, TLS_DHE_DSS_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA256]
kafka-producer-network-thread | console-producer, SEND TLSv1.2 ALERT:  fatal, description = certificate_unknown

Client connects without issue if https endpoint verification has not been enabled.

What I had in mind for the output is, if there are config keys `key.a`, `key.b`, `key.c`, `key.d`, with `key.a`, `key.b`, `key.c` in group `Group X` and `key.d` in group `Group Y`, the output being like

```
Group X
^^^^^^^^

``key.a``
  ...

``key.b``
  ...

``key.c``
  ...


Group Y
^^^^^^^^

``key.d``
  ...

```

so that the doc has section headers for each group. It would also be nice if for each group we are able to,

If you want an example to play with, https://gist.github.com/shikhar/3fd0fdc410c18dca7524f81ac242a266 can be pasted into `org.apache.kafka.common.config` and has a `main()` that calls `toRst()`. I'd expect to be able to generate the contents of https://raw.githubusercontent.com/confluentinc/kafka-connect-jdbc/master/docs/sink_config_options.rst from that.

I think we'd probably want to preserve a version that does not exercise any of the newer metadata (`group`, `orderInGroup`, `dependents`) since those are optional. Perhaps this version should be a new `toEnrichedRst()` call. /cc @Ishiihara @ewencp

Before any merge I think we'd want to sort out the extra merge commits that crept into this branch. Not sure what caused that. To fix I'd probably do something like -
- checkout trunk, get it current with apache/kafka repo, resets as required
- checkout this branch, note sha of HEAD
- git reset --hard trunk
- git cherry-pick $sha_from_above
- git push -f

@antonnazaruk Thanks for the find. And this behavior is actually by design with the following motivations:
1. Originally we implement the punctuate function based on `processing time`, i.e. it will be scheduled based on the system's wall-clock time and hence the function will be triggered even if there is no data arrived after the elapsed amount of time.

However one caveat of this semantics is that in bootstrapping, for example, when a day's data can be piped and processing within a few minutes (assuming the data traffic was not high), such `processing time driven punctuation` will have a problem as it is only based on elapsed wall-clock time.

Another example to think about if "session windows", as we are planning to add soon and to be implemented based on punctuate functions. In this case we should really trigger the function to expire a session, for example, based on `event time` but not on `processing time`.
1. So as a result we moved into `event time` driven punctuation, that is we reason about the current stream time based on received records' timestamps and only trigger the function when that stream time has elapsed. And as you observed if there is no incoming data, stream time will not be advanced and hence no punctuation will be triggered, and on the other hand if events are coming much faster than `processing time` then multiple punctuations will be triggered.

So both semantics have their pros and cons, but I would like to hear your opinions and if you have a better solution regarding this aspect.

Thank you @shikhar for your review comments.As my git history had multiple unmerged commits, reset/cherry pick did not work smoothly..I did a reset to commit id one prior to my first unmerged commit(of months back) to get just this commit.Please have a look.Mostly committers themselves cherry pick my last commit :-) Thanks.

General comment: all of the new benchmark methods do exactly the same thing (except for initialization of the KafkaStream Topology) . I'd refactor it to have a single method `runBenchmark(KafkaStreams streams, final String nameOfBenchmark, /*anything else needed*/)`
and call that with the appropriate parameters.
Likewise, the `ForEachAction` in each of the benchmarks is identical.
LGTM. @ijuma @guozhangwang Although this is exploration as part of KIP-63 I don't see a reason why the benchmark cannot be committed as is, since it's useful beyond KIP-63.
@dguy good point, will refactor, thanks!
@dguy refactored all except for `ForEachAction`. I could use a hint on how to refactor that one. Thanks.

@enothereska you can just refactor the `ForEachAction` to an inner class say `CountDownAction` it will just have a constructor that takes the `latch` as an argument.
Then in each of the methods you are building the topology you just do `ForEachAction action = new CountDownAction(latch);`

@enothereska It's really hard to write correct micro-benchmarks in the JVM by hand. That's why I strongly recommend JMH. So, if we want to merge this, then we need to review it to check that it is measuring what it claims to be measuring (I saw a potential problem in my very quick analysis).

It seems that @bbejeck was interested in contributing a JMH-based module for Kafka, I think that would be a better route, personally.
Thanks @dguy

Hi @guozhangwang !

Thanks for replying, and a level of details in answer!

Let me start with a use-case I have and then I'll bring my thoughts on framework's design.

My goal is to create a system that will perform change data capture from MySQL, aggregate data accordingly to logical business transaction that performed actual insert/update/delete and pass it to event-sourcing kafka topic. CDC is covered by KafkaConnect/Debezium (works smoothly in prototype). The most challenging part is aggregation. MySQL schema is normalized, so one incoming data portion that represents one business transaction (may come as JSON/XML/etc document or user's submit from UI) may be split among 10 tables. There are all kinds of relations (one-to-one, one-to-many and many-to-many) and couple of nested levels of relations between those tables. The requirement is to aggregate data from all supplemental tables around record in main table and pack that all into one kafka message to send to event sourcing topic. 

Initially, kafka streams DSL was promising technology to use. But, during prototyping we've noticed following issues (main ones):

**1)** KTable is not designed to be used for huge tables (billions of records). I realize that's not a framework gap and I agree with it's current design. Simple update (as a one business TX) of supplemental table doesn't trigger update of a main table (so there is no correspondent event in main table's topic with similar timestamp and stream-to-stream join won't work).
**2)** Joins of more than two streams is questionable. I am not sure how sliding window will work in case if it will be used N-1 times for N joins. I didn't continue testing this approach though.
**3)** Aggregation within one stream (one-to-many table case, where "many" records from related table have to be aggregated and become a part of one message) - aggregateByKey and reduceByKey don't have sliding window support (based on event's timestamp difference). It only uses system time to define window borders. 

The biggest issue with above approach (even if all above issues haven't been existed) is that the flow from debezium topics to event sourcing topic becomes very long... with many processing/transition points (message transformations to proper keys for joins, multi-stage joins, separate topologies with processors, etc, etc). From support/monitoring/troubleshooting perspective it seems to be to complex and error-prone. 

At this moment I consider global HBase storage for joins/aggregations with permanent store of all events (events are put to HBase by debezium topic's consumers). We already have HBase in place so it won't increase overall complexity. All joins/aggregates will be performed over data stored in HBase just by scanning supplemental/main records tables by key prefix in HBase table (very fast and scalable). Having global KV with ALL data in place brings many possibilities and strongest consistency guarantees.

Here is actually how this pull-request was created :

To resolve 3rd issue from above list I tried to use processor's API and rely on punctuate function. Idea is very similar to how words count example works - process method adds value to a list and puts to KVStore under it's key. Punctuate method on a periodic basis iterates through KVStore, checks value's elements timestamps, aggregates them by earliest ts + window, sends aggregated value (if time window is expired) in one message to output topic and removes it from KVStore. And because of an issue that punctuate is not calling if there are no new events -- latest aggregate won't be sent until new record arrives. 

I believe that my case is enough to at least consider addition of additional (configurable) punctuation logic. What I mean is an ability to specify punctuation behavior in topology builder (overloaded method addProcessor with new parameter PunctuationMode.[WALL_CLOCK|STREAM_TIME], or smth like that). In my HBase-based design punctuation is implemented via tick topic (tick msg keeps a key that needs to be aggregated from HBase pieces and is sent with linger.ms option in producer close to window time to not saturate processing with ticks). 

Also, another inconvenience that I noticed is that process method doesn't have event's time (one added in 0.10.0.0). So, in order to do any kinds of custom aggregations event's timestamp must be presented in event's value.

I hope above has at least some sense.
Thanks for the PR. Left a couple of minor comments, looks good otherwise. Do you think we should close the JIRA or keep it open for some time to see if the test fails again?
